The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
   
A.  Justification 
1.  The Government requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the International Fund 
for Agriculture Development (IFAD) to provide support for project preparation to ensure there is 
sound technical, financial and economic evidence to justify proceeding with the Project. The 
government will contribute to the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) in terms of 
staff and in-kind resources but does not have the capacity to prepare an investment project that 
will adhere to the requirements of ADB, IFAD, and the government.1  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will define the scope, cost, selection and prioritization of project activities, 
financing  plan,  implementation  arrangements,  procurement  strategy,  technology  issues, 
capacity development needs and post-project operation and maintenance arrangements. It will 
ensure adherence of the safeguard policies of ADB, IFAD and the government. The PPTA will 
provide  guidance  in  actions  to  maximize  the  socioeconomic  benefits  such  as  impacts  on 
poverty, gender and fair employment practices. The PPTA will detail a viable project design and 
prepare a feasibility study report (FSR). It will provide advance drafts of the complete set of 
documentation necessary for the ADB and IFAD to proceed with internal processing. Table 1 
summarizes the outputs and activities.

1  Originally a PPTA of $0.3 million was programmed to support the additional financing of the G0235-LAO Northern 
Rural Infrastructure Sector Project. The Government prioritized to proceed immediately with a new livestock project 
instead of additional financing for G0235-LAO. It was estimated that for a new project a total of $0.8 million is 
needed for the PPTA. The $0.3 million for G0235-LAO was reallocated to the new project PPTA and an additional 
0.5 million was approved by SERD.

2 
C.  Cost Estimates and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $0.80 million equivalent, on a grant basis from ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund V. The Lao Government will provide counterpart support in 
the form of counterpart staff, office space, facilities, supplies, and transportation. IFAD will 
provide  approximately  $0.12  million  and  internal  staff  resources  in  parallel  collaborative 
financing,  to  be  administered  by  IFAD,  in  technical  assistance  for  carrying  out  a  sector 
assessment which will include a livestock value chain analysis and recommendations on training 
programs  and  extension  delivery  systems.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  of  the  PPTA  are 
presented in Table 2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The PPTA will require services of 19 person-months (p-m) of international and 24 p-m of 
national consultants. The bulk of the services will be provided by a consulting firm, 18 p-m of 
international and 23 p-m of national consultants. The firm will be recruited through quality- and 
cost-based selection method (QCBS) using a quality-cost ratio of 80:20 and simplified technical 
proposal according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from 
time to time). Two individual independent consultants (1 p-m of international and 1 p-m of 
national) will be recruited by ADB to assist both the Government and ADB in quality and timely 
project processing. Table 3 provides details of the consultant requirements.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 6 to17. 
As a general principle, international specialists (IS) will have a minimum academic equivalent of 
a master’s degree, while the national specialists (NS) will have a minimum of an undergraduate 
degree in their areas of expertise and at least 10 years of experience relevant to their positions. 
Positions can be combined if specialists have the necessary qualifications and experience. All 
specialists shall contribute as appropriate to report and document preparation. The firm will 
administer workshops, seminars and training activities.  
6.  Team leader/deputy team leader and economist (IS 5 p-m; NS 6 p-m). The specialists 
shall: (i) with reference to the ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Project (1997), Key 
areas of Economic Analysis of Project: An overview (2003), and ADB’s Financial Management 
and Analysis of Projects (2005), assess the overall financial and economic Project viability; (ii) 
prepare FSR, project cost estimates and financing plan and liaison with other relevant projects; 
and (iii) lead in the preparation all reports required by ADB, including inception, interim, draft 
final, and final reports and a draft RRP and its linked documents. 
7.  Livestock farming systems and agribusiness value chain specialist (IS 2.75 p-m; 
NS  3.5  p-m). The  specialists  shall:  (i)  carry  out  an  analysis  of  the  selected  value  chains 
identifying market demand, geographic properties, gaps and obstacles within each; (ii) prepare 
preliminary interventions and measures to remove the gaps and obstacles in the value chains; 
and (iii) prepare a training program on livestock production and processing. 
8.  Public, Private Partnership specialist (IS 1.25 pm; NS 1 p-m) With respect to livestock 
industry the specialists will (i) review current contractual practices and relevant legal issues; (ii) 
provide outlines of approaches to optimize public private partnerships, in the management of 
livestock  infrastructure; (iii)  provide  outlines for  the  contractual  interface  between  producer 
groups,  traders  and  agribusinesses.  The  specialist  shall  assess  the  relevance  of  PPP 
experience in the Lao coffee industry. 
9.  Livestock infrastructure engineers (IS 1 p-m; NS 1 p-m). The specialists will work in 
coordination with the livestock and agribusiness value chain specialists to provide engineering 
input to market and livestock infrastructure design and costing.

4 
10.  Food safety specialists (IS 1 p-m; NS 1 p-m). The specialists will identify key problems 
concerning food safety in the value chains, particularly at the farm and the processing levels. 
The specialists will provide guidance for approaches to improve food safety systems as relevant 
to the project. 
11.  Social safeguard specialists (IS 1.5 p-m; NS 2.5 p-m). The specialists will prepare the 
work with the Social Development Specialists to carry out the surveys and analysis necessary to 
prepare the Involuntary Resettlement Plan and Indigenous Peoples Plan in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
12.  Social Development and Gender Specialist (IS 1.5; NS 2.5 p-m). The specialists will: 
(i) prepare the poverty reduction and social strategy, to conduct gender analysis, collect sex-
disaggregated baseline data and development of the gender action plan; and (ii) develop the 
stakeholder  analysis,  the  stakeholder  communication  strategy,  and  the  consultation  and 
participation plan. 
13.  Environment safeguard specialists (IS 1.5 p-m; NS 2.5 p-m). The specialists will pay 
particular attention to issues of waste management from farms and processing plants and any 
significant related climate change impacts. They will (i) establish baseline situation; (ii) assess 
possible  environmental  impacts  of  the  project;  and  (iii)  draft  appropriate  documentation  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
14.  Financial management specialists (IS 1.0 p-m; NS 1.5 p-m). The specialists must 
have  a  professional  accountancy  qualification  and  ensure  all  financial  management  due 
diligence as per ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects (2005). The specialists 
will: (i) design fund flow and disbursement mechanisms for the ensuing project and measures to 
mitigate any potential problems; (ii) assess and reach agreement on financial reporting, auditing 
and disclosure arrangements; (iii) conduct as appropriate, financial evaluations (financial cost-
benefit analyses) including sensitivity analyses; and (iv) prepare the financial management 
assessments. 
15.  Procurement specialist (IS 1 p-m; NS 1 p-m). The specialist will work with the financial 
management specialist and team leader to ensure governance and procurement due diligence 
is  carried  including  carrying  out  a  procurement  assessment  and  strategy  and  drafting  the 
procurement plan. 
16.  Advance  action  specialist  (IS  0.5  p-m;  NS  0.5  p-m).  Provide  assistance  to  the 
government for an efficient project start up. 
17.  Development  Specialist  –  individual  consultants  (IS  and  NS  1.5  p-m).  Provide 
independent quality review and support to the government and the ADB. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) will be the executing agency for the 
PPTA. The implementing agencies will be the provincial governments of Luang Namtha, Luang 
Prabang and Xieng Khouang. In kind contributions to be provided by the executing agency 
would include: office space, counterpart staff, office staff and translators, domestic transport and 
basic office and communications equipment and associated costs. Disbursements under the

5 
 
PPTA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s procedures.2 The Government was advised 
that approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing loan or grant. The 
PPTA will commence on 1 January 2014 with the final report completed by 30 September 2014. 
Thereafter support will be provided for advance actions for an efficient start up, with the PPTA 
closing on 30 June 2015. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in
